title: Madagascar might be the only place that will keep its planet-saving promises
text:
Daniel stood calmly on the sandy path with the little snake dangling from his finger, lit by the beam of our head torches. It was enthusiastically pumping all the venom it could muster into our leader’s hand. And it was my fault.

I was in Madagascar as “the expert”, so when I saw this pretty black-and-white snake beside the path on our night walk, I did the obvious thing – told Daniel to pick it up while I gave the group the benefit of my knowledge. “You see” I explained, “there are no venomous snakes in Madagascar, so you can safely handle any of them”.

“Actually” said Daniel, rather more knowledgeably, “some species are venomous, including this cat-eyed snake, but they are back-fanged”. He picked it up skilfully, but something went wrong and the snake managed to turn its head and sink its (back) fangs into Daniel’s finger. It could hardly believe its luck at finally getting its teeth into a human hand, and was not going to let go in a hurry. The considerable efforts of two guides were needed to persuade it to release its grip.
